attributes.title: Diversity in Undergraduate Admissions: Consensus or Disagreement among Students?

q1.value: Diversity in Undergraduate Admissions: Consensus or Disagreement among Students?

q2.value: Yusaku Horiuchi | John Michael Carey | Madeline M. Brown | Lauren K. Martin

q5.value: We are grateful to Dartmouth College's Office of Institutional Research for providing the contact information for our sample of student survey respondents.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This study investigates Dartmouth College students’ preferences for diversity with respect to race/ethnicity, gender, socioeconomic status and other important attributes in undergraduate admissions. Instead of directly asking diversity-related questions, which could produce social desirability bias, we employ a novel measurement technique based on conjoint analysis (Hainmueller, Hopkins, and Yamamoto 2014). To the best of our knowledge, the proposed study will be the first to empirically examine university students’ preferences for diversity in undergraduate admissions based on the method of conjoint analysis. We hope that it would make contributions not only to the academic literatures but also to actual policy debates on campus diversity in the United States.

q16.value: [H1] Students prefer admissions of non-white applicants, as compared to white applicants. [H1a] Students who do not identify themselves as white on race/ethnicity have stronger preferences for admissions of non-white applicants than do students who self-identify as white. [H1b] Positive affect on race/ethnicity is strongest when applicants’ race/ethnicity match students’ self-identification on race/ethnicity. [H2] Students prefer admissions of non-male applicants, as compared to male applicants. [H2a] Students who do not identify themselves as male have stronger preferences for admissions of non-male applicants than do students who identify as male. [H3] There is a broad-based priority for applicants with lower socioeconomic status relative to applicants with higher socioeconomic status. [H3a] Students from lower socioeconomic backgrounds have stronger preferences for admissions of applicants from lower socioeconomic backgrounds than do students from higher socioeconomic backgrounds.

q17.value: We juxtapose sets of composite persons as hypothetical applicants for undergraduate admissions at Dartmouth College and ask current Dartmouth students to choose the most preferred applicant. Our study identifies current students’ perspectives on the relative importance of various applicant attributes, such as race/ethnicity, gender, and socioeconomic status. By interacting the attributes of hypothetical applicants with the attributes of current students themselves, this approach also allows us to investigate whether there is any hidden consensus or disagreement on diversity in undergraduate admissions among students, such as between majority (i.e., white) students and minority students.

q19.value: 2,251 (# of respondents receiving an invitation to participate in the survey)

attributes.title: Working, Shirking, and Sabotage in Times of Democratic Backsliding: An Experimental Study in Brazil

q1.value: Working, Shirking, and Sabotage in Times of Democratic Backsliding: An Experimental Study in Brazil

q2.value: João Victor Guedes-Neto | B. Guy Peters

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Do bureaucrats work, shirk or sabotage when assigned to implement undemocratic projects? This research design proposes to answer this question based on an experimental study conducted in Brazil. It aims at capturing bureaucrats’ intention to shirk or sabotage when faced with projects that restrict democratic rights, as the freedom of expression and press. Furthermore, it considers a series of heterogeneous treatment effects, including administrative level, type of government job, leadership position, political appointment, discretion, and expected gains in a different job in the private sector. In the following sections, I describe the theory, hypotheses, research design (including data generation strategy), and methods for data analysis.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1: Bureaucrats are more prone to shirk when assigned to work in a project that restricts political liberties like freedom of expression or freedom of the press. Hypothesis 2: Bureaucrats are more prone to sabotage when assigned to work in a project that restricts political liberties like freedom of expression or freedom of the press. Hypothesis 3: Bureaucrats are more prone to shirk than to sabotage when assigned to work in a project that restricts political liberties like freedom of expression or freedom of the press. Hypothesis 4: Bureaucrats are more prone to shirk if assigned to work in a project that is perceived as bad for the country and harmful to citizens’ political rights than if assigned to a project that is bad for the country but not harmful to citizens’ political rights. Hypothesis 5: Bureaucrats have a higher propensity to shirk in face of projects that restrict political rights in comparison to projects that do not when they work for higher administrative levels (e.g., federal) than when they work for lower administrative levels (e.g., subnational). Hypothesis 6: Bureaucrats have a higher propensity to shirk in face of projects that restrict political rights in comparison to projects that do not when they are tenured (servidor público de carreira in Brazil) than when they are not tenured. Hypothesis 7: Bureaucrats have a lower propensity to shirk in face of projects that restrict political rights in comparison to projects that do not when they are responsible to supervise other civil servants than when they are not responsible to supervise others. Hypothesis 8: Bureaucrats have a lower propensity to shirk in face of projects that restrict political rights in comparison to projects that do not when they are political appointees (cargo de confiança) than when they are not political appointees. Hypothesis 9: Bureaucrats have a higher propensity to shirk in face of projects that restrict political rights in comparison to projects that do not when they have high discretion than when they do not have it. Hypothesis 10: Bureaucrats have a higher propensity to shirk in face of projects that restrict political rights in comparison to projects that do not when they think they could earn a higher salary in the private sector than when they do not think that.

q17.value: List experiments. As the subjects enter the online questionnaire, they will be presented with a list experiment. The control group will read four projects that potentially demotivate civil servants of carrying out regular tasks. The treatment group, on the other hand, will have access to five projects: the same four as the control group, plus “a project that restricts citizen’s political rights, for instance, freedom of expression or press.” The difference between the outcome of each group is the percentage of subjects affected by the treatment. I use the same design to ask about the possibility of sabotage. Vignette experiments. At the end of the questionnaire, the same subjects are presented with a scenario where Paulo, a fictional civil servant, is assigned to work on a project that he considers to be terrible to the country. He decides to shirk. Subjects are asked what the probability is that they would also have shirked. The control group receives a complementary vignette affirming that the project is not perceived to be harmful to the freedoms of expression and press. The treatment group is told that Paulo considers the project harmful to these freedoms. As in the case of the list experiment, the difference between the outcome of the treatment and the control groups is the effect of interest. Covariates and heterogeneous treatment effects. Before the list experiment, subjects are asked about their age range and whether they work for the public sector. In between the list and the vignette experiments, I ask questions related to discretion, administrative level, administrative power, years of experience, level of education, expected salary difference if working for the private sector, gender, her state, whether the subject supervises other people, is a tenured civil servant, and a political appointee.

q31.value: Subjects are informed that the aggregated and anonymized results will be used in research studies that may be published.

registration_responses.q2: João Victor Guedes-Neto | B. Guy Peters

attributes.title: Etiology and pathogenesis of depression.
attributes.description: The primary cause of depression is a violation of the physiological needs of the body. Violation of the fulfillment of physiological needs leads to stress. Chronic stress leads to neurodegenerative diseases.

q3.value: Found the cause of the spread of depression. The mechanism of development of depression is described. An association has been established between depression and neurodegenerative diseases.

q4.value: The cause of the spread of depression is the lack of satisfaction of a certain basic physiological need of the human body. Denote this need as X-need. Chronic deficiency in fulfilling the X-need leads to neurodegenerative diseases.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Previously unknown physiological characteristics of the human body were discovered. These physiological processes have been studied for over 20 years.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: Data has been accumulated for over 20 years. The study is individual and the object of study is the researcher.

question.value: The study is individual. The object of study is a researcher. Research has been conducted for over 20 years.

q13.value: The study was conducted on one person.

q14.value: The sample is limited to one person because of the complexity of the study and the uniqueness of the methods used.

q15.value: Observations have been conducted for more than 20 years. This is enough to determine the pattern.

question.value: Using special techniques, the deficiency or sufficiency of the presence of neurotransmitters in the human brain is clearly demonstrated.
Level of presence of neurotransmitters in the brain.
The research formula is know-how. Details of the study can be provided after determining the rights to the methods and tools that were used in the study.

q3.value: We aimed to address intergroup dynamics between participants who self-identified as Hispanic and targets from three ethnic groups, Hispanics, Hispanic-White Biracials, and Whites. Specifically, we investigated Hispanics’ perceptions of these targets and the relationship between target race, group membership, meta-perceptions, perceived avoidance from the target, and perceived avoidance from the participants’ racial ingroup (Study 1). A serial mediation analysis was conducted using PROCESS (Model 6; see Figure 1; Hayes, 2013) to test whether group membership, meta-perceptions, and target group avoidance sequentially mediated the relationship between target group and ingroup avoidance. Participants perceived the Hispanic-White Biracial target, b = -.15, SE = .06, 95% CI = [-.29, -.05], and the Hispanic target, b = -.21, SE = .09, 95% CI [-.41, -.06], as more of an ingroup member than the White target, which increased their expectations of being perceived positively, decreased expectations of being avoided by the target group, which in turn lead to reduced expectations that their group would be avoidant of the target group. The current study is a direct replication and is being proposed to determine if this effect is replicable.

q4.value: We hypothesize that Hispanics will perceive Hispanic, Hispanic-White, and White targets differently on all variables (i.e. group membership, meta-perceptions, target avoidance, and ingroup avoidance) with Hispanic targets being higher on group membership and meta-perceptions and lower on target avoidance and ingroup avoidance, followed be Hispanic-White Biracial and White targets. Further, we expect Hispanic-White Biracial targets to be rated significantly higher than the mid-point of the group membership scale (i.e. more ingroup member than equally ingroup and equally outgroup). Finally, we expect the relationship between the race of the target and the perceived ingroup avoidance of the participant would be mediated by group membership, meta-perceptions, and perceived target group avoidance, such that White targets will be perceived to be avoided by the participants’ ingroup more than Hispanic-White Biracials, while the same should be true for Whites compared to Hispanics. To test this hypothesis a categorical serial mediation model will be conducted.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the CUNY SONA system and will be asked to participate in an online study interested in people’s perceptions of others. Upon consent, participants will be (simply) randomly assigned to 1 of 3 target groups by being asked to take 30 seconds to think about the typical member of either Hispanics, Hispanic-White Biracials, or Whites. After being assigned to the target group, participants will complete the group membership, meta-perceptions, target avoidance, and ingroup avoidance measures. These measures will be randomly presented among several other measures. Participants will then be asked demographic questions and debriefed on the true purpose of this study.

q9.value: We will use simple randomization to assign participants to 1 of the 3 target groups, which is the main manipulation.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Although data for the proposed study have not already been collected, a prior study was conducted collecting data in an identical fashion as the proposed study. This is because the proposed study being preregistered is a direct replication of a study that has already been conducted.

question.value: Self-identified Hispanic participants will be recruited through the CUNY SONA system and will be asked to participate in an online study interested in people’s perceptions of others. Students may be offered partial course credit for their participation in this study however, no form of payment or any other benefit will be offered to the participants as a result of participating in this study. Only participants who self identify as Hispanic and complete all of the relevant measures will be included in the data analysis. We plan to continue to collect data until June 2020.

q13.value: We intend to collect roughly 160 participants.

q14.value: This sample size was determined by an a priori power analysis conducted in G*Power (Faul, Erdfedler, Lang, & Buchner, 2007).

q15.value: We will suspend recruitment after 200 participants have been run. This sample size includes number of participants that may be lost due to the potential for a loss of data through incomplete data.

question.value: Only the race of the target will be manipulated. Participants will be randomly assigned to 1 of the 3 target groups, Hispanic, Hispanic-White Biracial, and White.

Predictor/Mediators:

Group Membership. A modified version of a categorization measure used by Ho and colleagues (2011; see also Barrnett & Wout, 2016; Smith & Wout, 2019; Wout et al., under review) will be used to measure perceived group membership. Specifically, participants will be asked to respond to the question, “To what degree do you consider (target group) people to be a part of your racial group?” on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (completely outgroup) to 7 (completely ingroup). Importantly, the mid-point of the scale (4 = equally ingroup, equally outgroup) will be used to assess if participants considered the Hispanic-White Biracial target to be more of an ingroup member than equally ingroup and outgroup.

Meta-perceptions. The Stereotype Content Model (Fiske, Cuddy, Glick & Xu, 2002) will be used to assess how participants expected the target group to perceive their ingroup (i.e. other Hispanics). Specifically, participants will be asked to respond to “The typical (target group) person thinks that my racial group is              .” on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree) to five items measuring warmth (i.e. warm and friendly) and competence (i.e. competent, intelligent and smart). 

Target group avoidance. Four items will be used to measure the degree to which participants perceived that the target group desired to avoid their racial group. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with statements such as, “The typical (target group) person would rather not interact with members of my racial group” and “The typical (target group) person would prefer to avoid interacting with members of my racial group” on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly disagree). Two of the 4 items are reversed scored.

Criterion variable:

Ingroup avoidance. Four items will be used to measure the degree to which participants perceived that their racial group desired to avoid the target group. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with statements such as, “The typical member of my racial group would rather not interact with (target group) people” and “The typical member of my racial group would prefer to avoid interacting with (target group) people” on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly disagree). Two of the 4 items are reversed scored.

Exploratory criterion variable: we may decide to measure the participants' friendship interest by asking participants to rate on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 7 (very much) their agreement to the following statement, "I would be likely to pursue a friendship with the typical (target) person"

A separate One-way ANOVA will be conducted on each of the measures listed above (i.e. group membership, meta-perceptions, target avoidance, and ingroup avoidance) with target race as the between-subjects independent variable. Post-hoc analyses will be conducted for each ANOVA to test where the differences are which may include Tukey's or Bonferroni's tests. Additionally, a one-sample t-test against the midpoint of the group membership scale will be conducted. Finally, a multi-categorical serial mediation analysis will be conducted using PROCESS (Model 6; see Figure 1; Hayes, 2013) to test whether group membership, meta-perceptions, and target group avoidance sequentially mediate the relationship between the target group and ingroup avoidance. The White target condition will be the comparison group (White = 0) to the Hispanic (Hispanic = 1) and the Hispanic-White Biracial groups (Hispanic-White Biracial = 1).

q20.value: The multi-categorical variable of the target race will be coded with the White target as the comparison group (i.e. 0) to the Hispanic (i.e. 1) and the Hispanic-White Biracial group (i.e. 1) in a multi-categorical serial mediation model. It is possible that the Hispanic and Hispanic-White Biracials groups will be collapsed across (i.e. both a 1) if it is determined there are no differences between these two groups.

q21.value: p-values will be used for all tests as well as 95 % CIs (or Monte Carlo CIs) for all mediation analyses.

q22.value: Only incomplete or missing data will exclude data from analyses.

q23.value: Incomplete or missing data will exclude data from analyses.

q24.value: The multi-categorical serial mediation model listed above may be modified such that if group membership does not remain a significant mediation an identification and similarity measure might be used in its place. Furthermore, an analysis including a variable measuring participants likelihood of pursuing a friendship with the target might be included in the previously mentioned mediation analysis that that it would be the critereon variable.

Specifically, we investigated Hispanics’ perceptions of these targets and the relationship between target race, group membership, meta-perceptions, perceived avoidance from the target, and perceived avoidance from the participants’ racial ingroup (Study 1). A serial mediation analysis was conducted using PROCESS (Model 6; see Figure 1; Hayes, 2013) to test whether group membership, meta-perceptions, and target group avoidance sequentially mediated the relationship between target group and ingroup avoidance. Participants perceived the Hispanic-White Biracial target, b = -.15, SE = .06, 95% CI = [-.29, -.05], and the Hispanic target, b = -.21, SE = .09, 95% CI [-.41, -.06], as more of an ingroup member than the White target, which increased their expectations of being perceived positively, decreased expectations of being avoided by the target group, which in turn lead to reduced expectations that their group would be avoidant of the target group. Further, we expect Hispanic-White Biracial targets to be rated significantly higher than the mid-point of the group membership scale (i.e. more ingroup member than equally ingroup and equally outgroup). Finally, we expect the relationship between the race of the target and the perceived ingroup avoidance of the participant would be mediated by group membership, meta-perceptions, and perceived target group avoidance, such that White targets will be perceived to be avoided by the participants’ ingroup more than Hispanic-White Biracials, while the same should be true for Whites compared to Hispanics. To test this hypothesis a categorical serial mediation model will be conducted.

registration_responses.q15: We will suspend recruitment after 200 participants have been run. This sample size includes number of participants that may be lost due to the potential for a loss of data through incomplete data.
registration_responses.q20: The multi-categorical variable of the target race will be coded with the White target as the comparison group (i.e. 0) to the Hispanic (i.e. 1) and the Hispanic-White Biracial group (i.e. 1) in a multi-categorical serial mediation model. It is possible that the Hispanic and Hispanic-White Biracials groups will be collapsed across (i.e. both a 1) if it is determined there are no differences between these two groups.
registration_responses.q21: p-values will be used for all tests as well as 95 % CIs (or Monte Carlo CIs) for all mediation analyses.
registration_responses.q22: Only incomplete or missing data will exclude data from analyses.
registration_responses.q23: Incomplete or missing data will exclude data from analyses.
registration_responses.q24: The multi-categorical serial mediation model listed above may be modified such that if group membership does not remain a significant mediation an identification and similarity measure might be used in its place. Furthermore, an analysis including a variable measuring participants likelihood of pursuing a friendship with the target might be included in the previously mentioned mediation analysis that that it would be the critereon variable.
registration_responses.q8.question: Participants will be recruited through the CUNY SONA system and will be asked to participate in an online study interested in people’s perceptions of others. Upon consent, participants will be (simply) randomly assigned to 1 of 3 target groups by being asked to take 30 seconds to think about the typical member of either Hispanics, Hispanic-White Biracials, or Whites. After being assigned to the target group, participants will complete the group membership, meta-perceptions, target avoidance, and ingroup avoidance measures. These measures will be randomly presented among several other measures. Participants will then be asked demographic questions and debriefed on the true purpose of this study.
registration_responses.q12.question: Self-identified Hispanic participants will be recruited through the CUNY SONA system and will be asked to participate in an online study interested in people’s perceptions of others. Students may be offered partial course credit for their participation in this study however, no form of payment or any other benefit will be offered to the participants as a result of participating in this study. Only participants who self identify as Hispanic and complete all of the relevant measures will be included in the data analysis. We plan to continue to collect data until June 2020.
registration_responses.q16.question: Only the race of the target will be manipulated. Participants will be randomly assigned to 1 of the 3 target groups, Hispanic, Hispanic-White Biracial, and White.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Predictor/Mediators:

Group Membership. A modified version of a categorization measure used by Ho and colleagues (2011; see also Barrnett & Wout, 2016; Smith & Wout, 2019; Wout et al., under review) will be used to measure perceived group membership. Specifically, participants will be asked to respond to the question, “To what degree do you consider (target group) people to be a part of your racial group?” on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (completely outgroup) to 7 (completely ingroup). Importantly, the mid-point of the scale (4 = equally ingroup, equally outgroup) will be used to assess if participants considered the Hispanic-White Biracial target to be more of an ingroup member than equally ingroup and outgroup.

Meta-perceptions. The Stereotype Content Model (Fiske, Cuddy, Glick & Xu, 2002) will be used to assess how participants expected the target group to perceive their ingroup (i.e. other Hispanics). Specifically, participants will be asked to respond to “The typical (target group) person thinks that my racial group is              .” on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree) to five items measuring warmth (i.e. warm and friendly) and competence (i.e. competent, intelligent and smart). 

Target group avoidance. Four items will be used to measure the degree to which participants perceived that the target group desired to avoid their racial group. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with statements such as, “The typical (target group) person would rather not interact with members of my racial group” and “The typical (target group) person would prefer to avoid interacting with members of my racial group” on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly disagree). Two of the 4 items are reversed scored.

Criterion variable:

Ingroup avoidance. Four items will be used to measure the degree to which participants perceived that their racial group desired to avoid the target group. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with statements such as, “The typical member of my racial group would rather not interact with (target group) people” and “The typical member of my racial group would prefer to avoid interacting with (target group) people” on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly disagree). Two of the 4 items are reversed scored.

Exploratory criterion variable: we may decide to measure the participants' friendship interest by asking participants to rate on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 7 (very much) their agreement to the following statement, "I would be likely to pursue a friendship with the typical (target) person"
registration_responses.q19.question: A separate One-way ANOVA will be conducted on each of the measures listed above (i.e. group membership, meta-perceptions, target avoidance, and ingroup avoidance) with target race as the between-subjects independent variable. Post-hoc analyses will be conducted for each ANOVA to test where the differences are which may include Tukey's or Bonferroni's tests. Additionally, a one-sample t-test against the midpoint of the group membership scale will be conducted. Finally, a multi-categorical serial mediation analysis will be conducted using PROCESS (Model 6; see Figure 1; Hayes, 2013) to test whether group membership, meta-perceptions, and target group avoidance sequentially mediate the relationship between the target group and ingroup avoidance. The White target condition will be the comparison group (White = 0) to the Hispanic (Hispanic = 1) and the Hispanic-White Biracial groups (Hispanic-White Biracial = 1).

attributes.title: The Association of Relational Uncertainty with Relationship Satisfaction and Perceived Partner Responsiveness: Moderation Role of Political Ideology
attributes.description: This is a first study of a master's thesis on the association of relational uncertainty with relationship satisfaction and perceived partner responsiveness (PPR).

q1.value: The Association of Relational Uncertainty with Relationship Satisfaction and Perceived Partner Responsiveness: Moderation Role of Political Ideology

q3.value: This study will focus on the effects of relational uncertainty on relationship satisfaction and perceived partner responsiveness in romantic relationships. It will also examine this relationship whether or not affected by different political ideologies. There are a great number of studies showing that uncertainty is more unfavorable for conservatives or rightists than liberals or leftists (e.g. Jost, Glaser, Kruglanski, and Sulloway, 2003), but these studies focused on general or individual level uncertainties rather than relational based uncertainties. No previous study has investigated the effects of political ideology on relational uncertainty situation. This research will help to complete this gap in the literature by testing the role of political ideology on relationship outcomes such as satisfaction and PPR.

q4.value:
Relational uncertainty will be negatively associated with relationship satisfaction after controlling intolerance to uncertainty, attachment anxiety, and attachment avoidance.

Relational uncertainty will be negatively associated with perceived partner responsiveness (PPR) after controlling intolerance to uncertainty, attachment anxiety, and attachment avoidance.

We will also test the moderator role of different political orientations. We suspect that when the relational uncertainty is high, the relationship satisfaction and perceived partner responsiveness will be lower in relatively conservative individuals compared to relatively liberal individuals.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Study will be designed on Qualtrics as a survey. There will be no groups to assign participants but all scales and scale questions will be randomly presented to all participants. Participants will reach the survey via online Qualtrics link. The survey will consist of Relational Uncertainty Scale (Knobloch and Solomon, 1999; Gürcan, 2015), Ideological Orientation, Relationship Stability Scale (Rusbult, Martz, and Agnew, 1998; Büyükşahin, Hasta, and Hovardaoğlu, 2005), Perceived Partner Responsiveness (Reis, 2003; Taşfiliz, Sağel-Çetiner, and Selçuk (in press)), Experiences in Close Relationships-Revised (Fraley, Waller, and Brennan, 2000; Selçuk, Günaydın, Sümer, and Uysal, 2005), Intolerance to Uncertainty (Freeston, Rheaume, Letarte, Dugas, and Ladouceur, 1994; Buhr and Dugas, 2002; Sarı and Dağ, 2009) and demographic information form. The survey will start with an informed consent. After approving the consent, participants will respond to scale questions. All scales including the demographic information form will be presented in a random order.  After completing the survey, the participants will be debriefed and thanked.

q9.value: There is no randomization to assign participants to groups since there are no groups in the study. All scales including demographic questions will be randomized. All items within each scale will be randomized except the items of Relationship Stability Scale.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The survey link will be distributed to university students via course instructors and the participated students will be given course credits. Non-student individuals will be reached via social media such as Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram. Their participation will be voluntarily. All  individuals who are aged above 18 and have a current romantic relationship meanwhile or had at least one relationship in the past can participate the study. 

The participant who were very slow or very fast to complete the survey (-3 ad +3 z-scores distant from the mean duration time in Qualtrics) will be excluded from the study. 

In addition multivariate outliers (Mahalanobis distance, chi-square with a p smaller than .001) will be excluded from the study.

q13.value: We will need 436 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 500 participants considering possible dropouts.

q14.value: A power analysis with GPower (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, and Buchner, 2007) recommended 436 participants as sample size to detect interested effect size of .03 by 95% power and .05 alpha value. Considering possible drop outs and missing values in the data set, sample size is decided to be up to 500. Since we will explore a moderation effect of political orientation on the relationship between relational uncertainty and relationship satisfaction, and perceived partner responsiveness, we suspect a small moderated effect, thus selected f2 = .03.

q15.value: We will stop data collection when 500 individuals completed the survey.

question.value:
Demographic information form: Common demographics such as gender, age, highest educational level achieved will be measured in addition to current romantic relationship status, duration of the current romantic relationship, whether or not they have a long distance relationship, marital status. 

Social economical status will be measured by asking participants to state their (1) mothers' highest educational level achieved; (2) total household income; and (3) social ladder questions. 

Relational uncertainty: This scale was developed by Knobloch and Solomon (1999) and translated to Turkish by Gürcan (2015). Due to great numbers of questionnaires in the study, we will use the brief version of this scale (Knobloch and Theiss, 2011).

Ideological orientation: Participants will identify their ideological orientation by three questions. They will rate their political view from “0” (“very leftist”) and “100” (“very rightist”) and their ideological orientation from “0” (“very liberal”) and “100” (“very conservative”) by sliding a bar on the scale. At last, they will indicate how religious they were from “0” (“I do not have any religious affiliation”) to “100” (“very religious”) by sliding a bar on the scale. A factor analysis for these three questions will be performed to construct ideological orientation scale.

Relationship Stability Scale (relationship satisfaction and investment size subscales): Relationship satisfaction and investment size will be measured by the Relationship Stability Scale which was originally developed by Rusbult, Martz and Agnew (1998) and translated to Turkish by Büyükşahin, Hasta, and Hovardaoğlu (2005). 

Perceived Partner Responsiveness: This scale has generated by Reis (2003) and adapted to Turkish by Taşfiliz, Sağel-Çetiner and Selçuk (in press).

Experiences in Close-Relationships-Revised: This scale was originally formed by Fraley, Waller, and Brennan (2000) and adapted to Turkish by Selçuk, Günaydın, Sümer, and Uysal (2005).

Intolerance to uncertainty: This scale firstly formed by Freeston, Rheaume, Letarte, Dugas and Ladouceur (1994), adapted to English by Buhr and Dugas (2002) and translated to Turkish by Sarı and Dağ (2009).

A confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) will be conducted for Relational Uncertainty.
All other variables will be computed by having means. 
Political ideology items (n = 3) will be composed after exploratory factor analysis (EFA) if they load on the same factor, otherwise the left-right scale and religious affiliation scale will be used separately in further analyses. 
Another exploratory factor analysis for socio-economic status (SES) questions will be conducted.

Before the analyses three independent samples t test will be conducted to test if participants with a current relationship and rest will differ in self, partner, and relational uncertainty. If there is a significant difference at p smaller than .005, the further analyses will be carried separately in these two groups. 

Two separate hierarchical regression analysis will be performed to test main hypotheses. Intolerance to uncertainty, attachment anxiety,  attachment avoidance, long distance relationship, and relationship duration will be entered in the first level and partner uncertainty, self uncertainty, and relationship uncertainty will be entered in the second level of the regression equation when predicting perceived partner responsiveness and relationship satisfaction in two separate hierarchical regression analyses. 

Two moderation analyses will be performed to explore if political orientation moderates the relationship between relationship uncertainty and PPR and relationship satisfaction using Hayes' (2012) PROCESS model by 5000 bootstrapping re-samples. 

Two additional moderation analyses will be performed to explore if SES moderates the relationship between relationship uncertainty and PPR and relationship satisfaction using Hayes' (2012) PROCESS model by 5000 bootstrapping re-samples.

q22.value:
The participant who were very slow or very fast to complete the survey (-3 ad +3 z-scores distant from the mean duration time in Qualtrics) will be excluded from the study. 

In addition multivariate outliers (Mahalanobis distance, chi-square with a p smaller than .001) will be excluded from the study. 

Data of participants who met the inclusion criteria will be used in all analyses.

q23.value: Pairwise deletion will be used to exclude participants from the analyses.

q24.value:
Two moderation analyses will be performed to explore if political orientation moderates the relationship between relationship uncertainty and PPR and relationship satisfaction using Hayes' (2012) PROCESS model by 5000 bootstrapping re-samples. 

Two additional moderation analyses will be performed to explore if SES moderates the relationship between relationship uncertainty and PPR and relationship satisfaction using Hayes' (2012) PROCESS model by 5000 bootstrapping re-samples. 

We expect that political orientation may be related to investment size and investment size may influence to relational uncertainty. We also expect that some demographics such as age, gender, variables related to relationship may influence the study outcomes. Thus, we will explore data in terms of these variables.

q25.value:
References:

Amodio, D. M., Jost, J. T., Master, S. L., and Yee, C. M. (2007). Neurocognitive correlates of liberalism and conservatism. Nature Neuroscience, 10(10), 1246-1247. doi:10.1038/nn1979

Buhr, K., and Dugas, M. J. (2002). The intolerance of uncertainty scale: psychometric properties of the English version. Behaviour Research and Therapy, 40(8), 931-945. doi:10.1016/S0005-7967(01)00092-4

Büyükşahin, A., Hasta, D., and Hovardaoğlu, S. (2005). İlişki İstikrarı Ölçeği (İİÖ): Geçerlik ve güvenirlik çalışması. Türk Psikoloji Yazıları, 8(16), 25-35.

Faul, F., Erdfelder, E., Lang, A.-G., and Buchner, A. (2007). G*Power 3: A flexible statistical power analysis program for the social, behavioral, and biomedical sciences. Behavior Research Methods, 39(2), 175-191.

Fraley, R. C., Waller, N. G., and Brennan, K. A. (2000). An item response theory analysis of self-report measures of adult attachment. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 78(2), 350-365. doi:10.1037//0022-3514.78.2.350

Freeston, M. H., Rhéaume, J., Letarte, H., Dugas, M. J., and Ladouceur, R. (1994). Why do people worry? Personality and Individual Differences, 17(6), 791-802. doi:10.1016/0191-8869(94)90048-5

Gürcan, T. (2015). İlişkisel belirsizlik: İlişki doyumu, romantik ilişkilerde gelecek zaman yönelimi ve çatışma çözme tepkileri arasındaki ilişkiler. (Yayınlanmamış yüksek lisans tezi). Ankara Üniversitesi, Ankara.

Gromet, D. M., Kunreuther, H., and Larrick, R. P. (2013). Political ideology affects energy-efﬁciency attitudes and choices. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 110(23), 9314-9319. doi:10.1073/pnas.1218453110

Hayes, A. F. (2012). PROCESS: A versatile computational tool for observed variable mediation, moderation, and conditional process modeling [White paper]. Retrieved from http://www.afhayes.com/ public/process2012.pdf 

Jost, J. T. and Amodio, D. M. (2012). Political ideology as motivated social cognition: Behavioral and neuroscientiﬁc evidence. Motivation and Emotion, 36(1), 55-64. doi:10.1007/s11031-011-9260-7

Jost, J. T., Glaser, J., Kruglanski, A. W., and Sulloway, F. J. (2003). Political conservatism as motivated social cognition. Psychological Bulletin, 129(3), 339-375. doi:10.1037/0033-2909.129.3.339

Knobloch, L. K., and Solomon, D. H. (1999). Measuring the sources and content of relational uncertainty. Communication Studies, 50(4), 261-278. doi:10.1080/10510979909388499

Knobloch, L. K., and Theiss, J. A. (2011). Depressive symptoms and mechanisms of relational turbulence as predictors of relationship satisfaction among returning service members. Journal of Family Psychology, 25(4), 470-478. doi:10.1037/a0024063

Napier, J. L. and Jost, J. T. (2008).  Why are conservatives happier than liberals? Psychological Science, 19(6), 565-572. doi:10.1111/j.1467-9280.2008.02124.x

Reis, H. T. (2003). A self-report measure of perceived partner responsiveness. (Unpublished study), University of Rochester, Rochester, NY.

Rusbult, C. E., Martz, J. M., and Agnew, C. R. (1998). The investment model scale: Measuring commitment level, satisfaction level, quality of alternatives, and investment size. Personal Relationships, 5(4), 357-391. doi:10.1111/j.1475-6811.1998.tb00177.x

Sarı, S., and Dağ, I. (2009). Belirsizliğe Tahammülsüzlük Ölçeği,  Endişe ile İlgili Olumlu İnançlar Ölçeği ve Endişenin Sonuçları Ölçeği’nin Türkçeye uyarlanması, geçerliliği ve güvenilirliği. Anadolu Psikiyatri Dergisi, 10(4), 261-270.

Selçuk, E., Günaydın, G., Sümer, N., and Uysal, A. (2005). Yetişkin bağlanma boyutları için yeni bir ölçüm: Yakın İlişkilerde Yaşantılar Envanteri-II’nin Türk örnekleminde psikometrik açıdan değerlendirilmesi. Türk Psikoloji Yazıları, 8(16), 1-11.

Taşfiliz, D., Sağel-Çetiner, E., and Selçuk, E. (basım aşamasında). Yakın ilişkilerde algılanan duyarlılığın yaş farklılıkları ve psikolojik esenlik ile ilişkisi. Türk Psikoloji Dergisi.

Theiss, J. A. and Nagy, M. E. (2013). A relational turbulence model of partner responsiveness and relationship talk across cultures. Western Journal of Communication, 77(2), 186-209. doi:10.1080/10570314.2012.720746

In addition multivariate outliers (Mahalanobis distance, chi-square with a p smaller than .001) will be excluded from the study.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Demographic information form: Common demographics such as gender, age, highest educational level achieved will be measured in addition to current romantic relationship status, duration of the current romantic relationship, whether or not they have a long distance relationship, marital status. 

Social economical status will be measured by asking participants to state their (1) mothers' highest educational level achieved; (2) total household income; and (3) social ladder questions. 

Relational uncertainty: This scale was developed by Knobloch and Solomon (1999) and translated to Turkish by Gürcan (2015). Due to great numbers of questionnaires in the study, we will use the brief version of this scale (Knobloch and Theiss, 2011).

Ideological orientation: Participants will identify their ideological orientation by three questions. They will rate their political view from “0” (“very leftist”) and “100” (“very rightist”) and their ideological orientation from “0” (“very liberal”) and “100” (“very conservative”) by sliding a bar on the scale. At last, they will indicate how religious they were from “0” (“I do not have any religious affiliation”) to “100” (“very religious”) by sliding a bar on the scale. A factor analysis for these three questions will be performed to construct ideological orientation scale.

Relationship Stability Scale (relationship satisfaction and investment size subscales): Relationship satisfaction and investment size will be measured by the Relationship Stability Scale which was originally developed by Rusbult, Martz and Agnew (1998) and translated to Turkish by Büyükşahin, Hasta, and Hovardaoğlu (2005). 

Perceived Partner Responsiveness: This scale has generated by Reis (2003) and adapted to Turkish by Taşfiliz, Sağel-Çetiner and Selçuk (in press).

Experiences in Close-Relationships-Revised: This scale was originally formed by Fraley, Waller, and Brennan (2000) and adapted to Turkish by Selçuk, Günaydın, Sümer, and Uysal (2005).

Intolerance to uncertainty: This scale firstly formed by Freeston, Rheaume, Letarte, Dugas and Ladouceur (1994), adapted to English by Buhr and Dugas (2002) and translated to Turkish by Sarı and Dağ (2009).
registration_responses.q18.question:
A confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) will be conducted for Relational Uncertainty.
All other variables will be computed by having means. 
Political ideology items (n = 3) will be composed after exploratory factor analysis (EFA) if they load on the same factor, otherwise the left-right scale and religious affiliation scale will be used separately in further analyses. 
Another exploratory factor analysis for socio-economic status (SES) questions will be conducted.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Before the analyses three independent samples t test will be conducted to test if participants with a current relationship and rest will differ in self, partner, and relational uncertainty. If there is a significant difference at p smaller than .005, the further analyses will be carried separately in these two groups. 

Two separate hierarchical regression analysis will be performed to test main hypotheses. Intolerance to uncertainty, attachment anxiety,  attachment avoidance, long distance relationship, and relationship duration will be entered in the first level and partner uncertainty, self uncertainty, and relationship uncertainty will be entered in the second level of the regression equation when predicting perceived partner responsiveness and relationship satisfaction in two separate hierarchical regression analyses. 

Two moderation analyses will be performed to explore if political orientation moderates the relationship between relationship uncertainty and PPR and relationship satisfaction using Hayes' (2012) PROCESS model by 5000 bootstrapping re-samples. 

Two additional moderation analyses will be performed to explore if SES moderates the relationship between relationship uncertainty and PPR and relationship satisfaction using Hayes' (2012) PROCESS model by 5000 bootstrapping re-samples.

attributes.title: Origins and Maintenance of Automaticity (OMA)
attributes.description: The OMA study is seeking to analyze different patterns of smartphone usage and their impact on people's well-being using both quantitative and qualitative methods.

q1.value: Origins and Maintenance of Automaticity (OMA) Study

q2.value: Parker Dexter Anderson, Robert M Montgomery, Abraham M. Rutchick, Omar Ruvalcaba

q4.value: The study is exploratory. We're interested in seeing how passive sensor data correlates with self-reports of automaticity based on the review of mobile behavior captured on video.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be California State University, Northridge undergraduate students recruited using the Sona System and will be awarded credits they are required to obtain for an undergraduate course. The study will run from February to May of 2020.

Inclusion Criteria
Participants must be of at least 18 years of age, have normal or corrected -to-normal vision and hearing, and be in possession of a smartphone mobile device with at least 50MB of free storage space.

Exclusion Criteria
Participants are not eligible to participate in this study if they do not have corrected 20/20 vision or corrected-to-normal hearing, or if they do not own a smartphone mobile device with 50MB of free storage space.

q13.value: Data collection will end when we have collected 180 participants or when the Spring semester ends, whichever one comes sooner.

question.value:
Passive phone use data will be collected using sensors from AWARE Client V2. Sensor data will consist of accelerometer, activity recognition, device usage, weather, battery, communication (whether a call or message event occurs), gyroscope, rotation, and whether the screen is on or off. Accelerometer, gyroscope, and rotation data will be collected once per second.

A set of event-based multiple-choice questions detailing what they believe motivated their actions when they began using their phone, switched between apps on their phone, and stopped using their phone will be used. Every time the participant is asked one of these questions, they will be asked to measure how automatic or deliberate their phone use was on a 7-point Likert scale (1 being 'very automatic', 7 being 'very deliberate'). This question will be asked in thirty-second intervals after the beginning of any application that is being used. All of these questions have been attached.

After, participants will partake in a qualitative interview on smartphone use and well-being.
The analysis will be exploratory. No specific hypotheses at present.
